In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Here is the code:

```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime; bump=3)
    if typeof(dt) == Date
        throw(ArgumentError("The function works only with DateTime types and throws an error for Date types."))
    end
    dt + Hour(bump)
end
```
This function `timezone_bumper` takes a DateTime type as input. If the input is not of DateTime type, it throws an ArgumentError stating that it works only with DateTime types and does not work with Date types. If the input is correct, it returns the DateTime value increased by bump hours. 

You can use this function like so:
```julia
dt = now()
bump_dt = timezone_bumper(dt)
print(bump_dt)
```
This will print the current date and time, but with an additional 3 hours added to it.
